title: Outback duo's 'excellent' homemade backyard BBQ innovation: 'Works perfectly'
text:
Tom Forrest and his grandfather Stephen, dubbed ‘Outback Grandad’, share glimpses into their life in Western Australia's Kimberley region.

Stephen Forrest and his grandson Tom have shared a step-by-step guide to how to make a backyard Korean Barbecue with recycled materials. Source: Tom Forrest/Outback Tom/TikTok

For the past few years, a popular Aussie duo have been entertaining millions around the world with videos of their bush adventures.

From whipping up pizzas and cinnamon scrolls by a campfire, to clever DIY projects like turning old trees into bird boxes, Tom Forrest and his grandfather Stephen, 72, delightfully dubbed ‘Outback Grandad’, have garnered many fans with glimpses into their life in Western Australia's Kimberley region.

Most recently, the pair debuted a handmade backyard Korean BBQ in their signature “bush style” and constructed entirely out of recycled materials. Viewers have praised the “excellent” idea.

Speaking to Yahoo News Australia, Tom said the pair designed the project after he moved back to the area from Sydney. “I’d never heard of Korean barbecue before until I’d essentially travelled to the city,” he said.

ADVERTISEMENT

After dining at a few restaurants, not only did Tom become a fan of the food, but he enjoyed the inclusivity of having everyone gathered around a central grill, cooking and eating together.

“When I think about backyard barbecues in the Outback or across the country, I sort of recognise that it separates the cook from the rest of the people,” he told Yahoo. “It’s typically one person’s responsibility to cook the barbecue and then bring the food over.

“So I took inspiration from the Korean barbecue set-up and wanted to bring that to the Outback and basically create this 44-gallon drum contraption which could seat up to five people.”

Backyard Korean BBQ crafted from recycled materials

In a video posted to TikTok, the pair took other Aussies through a step-by-step guide of how to create their own backyard Korean BBQ using items they may have stashed in the back of a shed.

ADVERTISEMENT

“The foundation of the Korean barbecue is a 44 gallon drum. These are really popular in the Kimberley, so we have access to them relatively easy,” Tom said. The next key component is finding a “mini charcoal barbecue”, which can be found in most camping stores, and will sit inside a hole cut out of the top of the drum.

“We then took a piece of plywood to use for our table and cut a hole in the interior part of the board so we could slide the board over the 44-gallon drum, and then we also cut a circle on the exterior part of the board so that we had a round table,” Tom explained. After then it’s just a matter of putting all the pieces together.

How can I make a Korean BBQ like Outback Grandad?

Cut a hole in the top of the of the 44-gallon drum so the mini charcoal barbecue sits flush on top.

Make four steel L-shaped brackets to hold the plywood table. Drill them into the side of the drum, making sure they are “nice and level”.

Cut a hole in the interior part of a large piece of plywood so you can slide it over the drum.

Cut a circle on the exterior part of the board to form a round table with a hole in the centre.

Smooth the edges of the wood using a sander and apply a coat of lacquer so it can be easily wiped with a cloth.

Place the drum in its desired location.

Put the barbecue in the hole, place heated charcoals inside and the grill on top.

Slide the table over the drum and rest it on the brackets.

Cook up a feast for friends and family.

Stephen and Tom created the backyard Korean BBQ using a 44-gallon drum, a mini charcoal barbecue, and a piece of plywood. Source: Tom Forrest/Outback Tom/TikTok

Outback duo pleased as DIY project 'works perfectly'

Tom told Yahoo he and his grandad also added an airflow vent to help control the temperature, but it is probably not necessary.

ADVERTISEMENT

“We also cut out a hole in the side of the drum, so we could reach our hand through to adjust the air flow of the charcoal barbecue. If we want more heat, we can open it up to allow more oxygen to come in, and if we need the charcoal grill less hot, we can close that and reduce the oxygen intake as well,” he said.

The vent is lined with a rubber seal the pair pulled off of an old car on the back of their rural property. It prevents any cuts or grazes from the sharp edges of the hole.

“The concept and the design started off as a drawing, and then to finally have it in the backyard, get the charcoal barbecue cranking, have marinated meats and various side dishes on the table — I then invited the rest of the family out the back to join us — and it worked absolutely perfectly,” Tom said.
